desc: PNRC1 encodes the proline-rich nuclear receptor coactivator 1, which modulates the transcriptional activation of many nuclear receptors and stimulates transcription by RNA polymerase III through direct binding with its subunit RPC39 (PMID: 7578250, 10894149, 17612402). The proline-rich Src homology domain-3 of PNRC1 binds to the ligand-binding AF2 domain of a variety of nuclear receptors in a ligand-dependent and -independent manner. Among these, the nuclear receptors—estrogen receptor α and β, progesterone receptor, androgen receptor, glucocorticoid receptor, thyroid hormone receptor, retinoic acid receptor and retinoin X receptor—bind PNRC1 in a ligand-dependent manner, whereas the orphan receptors—steroidogenic factor 1 and estrogen-related receptor α 1—interact with PNRC1 in a ligand-independent manner (PMID: 23925889, 17068076, 15604093). In addition to its function as a modulator of transcription, PNRC1 plays an important role in the Ras-MAPK pathway, where it downregulates the signaling cascade through its interaction with Grb2 (PMID: 15122321). All of these functions are exploited in the nucleus of the cell, where PNRC1 is mainly localized—specifically, in the nucleoli (PMID: 20888865). PNRC1 is widely expressed in normal tissue. Downregulation of PNRC1 has been observed in various tumoral tissues, including breast, gastric, hepatocellular and colorectal carcinomas; treatment with 5-azacytidine can lead to induction of PNRC mRNA in a time-dependent manner (PMID: 15122321, 11768609). Deletion of PNRC1 has been observed in prostate and pancreatic adenocarcinoma and B-cell lymphoma, whereas copy number alterations have been seen in breast cancer (cBioPortal, MSKCC, Nov. 2015).

desc: PNRC1 is a nuclear receptor activator that modulates transcription of a variety of nuclear receptors. It is widely expressed in normal tissue, whereas downregulation and, in some cases, upregulation have been observed in solid cancers, including breast, gastric, hepatocellular and colorectal carcinomas.
